title: Type Designer's Work Ethic
content:
I was just reading the Myfonts.com March 2007 Rising Stars newslettter, and I happened to see the following quote from Rebecca Alaccari of Canada Type:

<cite>Both Patrick and I put in an average of 10 to 12 work hours a day, 6 days of most weeks.</cite>

Damn. I also saw a recent post where someone mentioned if you couldn't sit in front of a computer for more than 3 hours at a time you probably aren't cut out for the type design business.

So what's the scale? What's reasonable? I understand that it takes a long time to create a typeface, but there's got to be a line somewhere. All work and no sleep or play makes Dan Gayle a grumpy mean person with bad hair and no girlfriend.

What do you think is typical for the industry?
author: DanGayle

comments.content:
I don't know.  
But I usually work about 10 hours per day and only sometimes I take the weekends off.

I think that type design is more a passion than a profession.  
Anyway, if we look to Hermann Zapf we can say that type design must be a healthy exercise ;^)

Dino

A recent study looked at the careers of successful people in many walks of life, and compared them with those "most likely to" from school days. Did the ones who did best at school do best in later life? Maybe. But in whatever field, it was found that you have to work crazy hours for ten years to get to the top.
I think the life of a mendicant monk sounds attractive right now.

Leslie Cabarga's Logo and Lettering book has a nice albeit brief summary about the hours many of the font designers including me invest in working. Page 235 - I, Designaholic section . . .

Personally I have 3 full workdays when the kiddos are in school and they run from 8:30 till 5:00 with a 20 minute lunch. On the other days, I'm checking and replying to e-mail about every 2-3 hours or so and making or taking phone calls throughout the day else I'm pre-planning my workload for my full workdays. Some evenings for 2-3 hours after the kids go to bed are spent working as well if the mood strikes me.

It's not optimal in terms of my desired output of work or the required focus of fontmaking when you're in the groove so to speak but I've lowered my expectations of the quantity I'm able to produce a bit and am pleased with what I am able to produce. I've also spent time delegating work that I feel doesn't require my expertise which explains all the phone calls.

Overall, the family thing is a much bigger deal for me so it deserves my primary focus and everything else can fall out of the time not spent with my family.

Stuart :D

My full-time job and commute subtracts 11 hours from my day (for the timebeing anyway). I have a wife and 2 kids but they are not young and all-consuming like they used to be :-)  
This leaves me some amount of time for sleeping, eating, etc. I play tennis a couple of times a week and take voice lessons. All the rest is spent designing type, not because I have to but because I want to. I would love to be able to spend 12 hours a day designing type. I enjoy the time I do get to now. Since I am retiring in June, I will have more time to give it a go. Dino is right, as is James Montalbano of your 12 hour quote, designing type is a passion, not a job. Those who are not passionate about it probably won't do it for very long.

I find it's different when I'm working on commissioned work vs. my own retail work. I think to some degree, having a commercial project "forces" me to be creative and meet deadlines, generally working 10+ hour days during daylight hours.

On the other hand, with my personal projects, it's only the creativity that is tough to come by. I can sit at the computer day and night only stopping for brief periods of sustenance when the creativity is there.

We're all subject to diminishing returns, as the rate plateaus, but the trick is to keep working and squeezing out incremental improvements, keeping going rather than just spinning wheels.

We have lost the respect of the outside world who will step on/spit on - and don't understand the talent or hours that are spent on each job. (In this case type design, in others, just design itself.)

Yes, not only do we spend so many hours in front of a screen and a keyboard - we suffer for it with lack of exercise and fresh air.

Addition: or give up valuable downtime - because someone needs it NOW -- and our rest periods do not count toward our healths - ever notice how everyone else's priority is more important than your own?

As for work ethics, if deadlines didn't exist I would never get anything done. I do my best work under pressure--but not so much that I can't see straight. Just enough to add some adrenaline.

Balance is hard, not least because it's dynamic - if you ever stop vying for it, things are guaranteed to tip over. And this is why an eternal student is the only way to be.

_Nick, try selling complete sh\*t - and you’ll quickly get to the truth of “…being my own boss enables me to design whatever the f\*ck I want,” . Nice rhetoric, but that dog won’t hunt._

While I wouldn't categorize any of my work as complete sh\*t, things don't always turn out as expected, and following an idea for a typeface to its conclusion doesn't always result in what I would consider great usability. However, I'm not the one who ultimately decides on usability, and the classic example of that is the art directors who take micro type (Bell, Freight Micro) and use it in completely the "wrong" way, huge.

As a business model, I subscribe to the notion that I should make many fonts, and have many distributors. Potentially, my market is over half a billion computer users, and the internet reaches worldwide. So, according to the "long tail" theory, there is always someone somewhere who will see something in the obscure end of a product line, and the outcome is that the big sellers don't account for the majority of sales. _And I didn’t see anything important/original with your Softmachine - sorry bro, it’s a commercial bastardization of great work done way back. And we’re now getting to the truth of ‘The business of Type’._

I'm sorry you are so jaded that you fail to recognize genuine originality. As far as I am aware, nobody has previously made a font specifically for digital outlining, despite that effect having been around twenty years; and no type designer has used contextual alternates to optimize the appearance of stroking. These features may not be a big deal, but they are original. Yes, it's "commercial", but aren't all published fonts (except freeware) -- so that's not much of diss. And bastardization? Well sure, I didn't invent rounded type! -- but I drew Softmachine from scratch, not based on any particular model. Would you care to mention the sources which you think I ripped off?

_If you want to design an important/original typeface, then design of our time. Show something of ourselves never seen before. And that will involve putting Type ahead of business._

Maybe. But that phenomenon could also be explained by the coupling of the recent so-called "democratization" of type design with the long-standing "ennuie of the affluent" in the West.

\> nobody has previously made a font specifically for digital outlining

To repeat from the Softmachine thread: it seems like this is not true, since the layering of purposefully-spaced weights is effectively the same as outlining.

hhp

_In the neighborhood where I grew up, making books would have been considered a respected profession_

Be grateful you're not a person who does rugs with a latch tool.

Better to be a bookie than a hooker.... ;-)

_it seems like this is not true, since the layering of purposefully-spaced weights is effectively the same as outlining._

But it is true, because layering is a quite different process than outlining, requiring overlpapping text boxes or layers, which are much more of a hassle to work with than creating an outline by applying a stroke value. For instance, if you decide to edit the text, or adjust the size, or kerning or tracking in a layered setting, you have to do so in each and every layer, and that multiplies the confusion between stroke and fill button choices. There may also be problems with layer alignment, caused by the layout application's interpretation of character placement. Furthermore, layering is not infinitely adjustable, whereas stroke width is. These are significant practical differences.

And finally, the lower case character shapes and general proportions of Softmachine were designed specifically to accomodate an outline stroke of precise thickness.
Hiroshige who the \*\*\*\* do you think you are coming into a placve like this and slagging type design? Prick.

keep in mind Nick said **part of the time** he gets to do what he wants. Which is better than some jobs...

"Yeah, boss, I think after lunch I'm gunna take a few hours to dig a ditch over there instead of here like you said. I just have a feeling that it would be good. Whahdya mean 'fired'?"

This is getting too off-topic, but...

\> layering is a quite different process than outlining

Mechanically they're different, but the result is pretty much the same; a graphic designer is simply given a different way to do a very similar thing (and what else is new?). The advantage of outlining is indeed convenience, but: layering isn't as complex as you describe - all you need is to copy-paste the text box in place and change the font (assuming a set-up like Advert Rough where the fonts are spaced with that purpose); multiple weights allow the designer to design the outline, not leave it to a dumb algorithm; and the different weights provided in a layered scheme are: more fool-proof, in that a user is much less likely to apply tracking to a fatter version (since in layering the fonts are canned while in outlining they're sort of made by the end-user anyway) thus ruining your careful spacing; and being available as different weights, are more... convenient!

\> layering is not infinitely adjustable, whereas stroke width is.

True, but:  
1) It's not hard to provide a finely gradated weight range.  
And hey, people will think they're getting more for the money. :-)  
2) There's an upper limit to how much outlining one would use: beyond a certain point there's no whitespace left between the letters, so your scheme becomes moot.

\> the lower case character shapes and general proportions  
\> of Softmachine were designed specifically to accomodate  
\> an outline stroke of precise thickness.

?  
How does that jive with your "infinitely adjustable"? And how does a user know what that precise thickness should be? Don't tell me you expect graphic designers to pay attention... and then actually follow advice to boot! :-/

Anyway, don't get me wrong, outlining is probably a more cost-effective way of getting typically-desired results, but it does seem to be more brittle (opposite of robust) and less powerful than layering.

hhp

Getting back on topic, I agree the main key here is having the passion as so many others mentioned earlier. If you really love what you do and allow that creative force driving you, you don't think much about the time invested.
Too put this into context, does any of this make it more efficient, so that a designer doesn't have to work into the middle of the night?

Dan I think you're referring to something called the 'work/life balance' here, and it's something that artisans and craftspeople of all stripes generally have a difficulty with. It might sound awful, but there are any number of 'personal lifestyle coaches' out there who will take your money in return for telling you not to work so late into the night...

I used to work very hard all day, every day, when I was a freelance designer; I still work hard, but nowadays I'm more interested in having a workload that's compatible with my life. Having said that, a particular project like a typeface deserves to be worked on intensively.

If you've set yourself a personal deadline about finishing or releasing your type design, whilst meeting your other commitments, then pulling a string of all nighters is probably the only way it's going to get done.

"So what’s the scale? What’s reasonable? I understand that it takes a long time to create a typeface, but there’s got to be a line somewhere..."

Oh? the only lines I've ever drawn on time and effort end up on my face. The hours per day, I see as more related to the physical state, the mental state is an hours per career thing, as far as I know. e.g. I finished some fonts last year that I started in 1997. This year, I will finish some fonts I started in 1999 and I'm starting fonts now that might not be finished until 2011, or so.

The big thing is to get over hump between rolling eyes, and knowing nods, for support on these long typographic trips.

Greetings everyone!!!

This is my first post on this cool website!!!

I work 10 hour days in central London, try not to work weekends but it happens esp if there's a deadline looming...!

Dan, sometimes it is fun to be drawn in to long nights and obsessive sessions, other times it is not. If the passion of type is in you, I tihnk you should indulge them occasionally. Just like excess, moderation is only healthy in moderation.

Some nights, I am up until 4:30 am, when I've got to bright-eyed and bushy-tailed at work in 3 1/2 hours. If I am enjoying AND productive AND have the mental acuity to make that time worthwhile, I think thats good. But I can't do or recommend it everyday. Everyone has their limits.

Keep in mind, this is supposed to be largely for fun for me.The dry work and the file wrangling is a side affect of trying to make something impressive enough to appear as viable product to others. IT isn't the type design at all.

If I am kerning accents for a language I don't speak, or tediously working round a clumsy part of a software-work flow by manually repeating an action, I tend to call it quits earlier. I can usually do that stuff far faster when I start my work period, and my mood will be better, too.

If you have a girlfriend, make time for her. If you don't want to, and you'd rather do type, why are you (hypothetically) dating? If you are certain about type, think about what you want to get out of it. "Name in lights", a paycheck, the respect of peers, mad experiments, a teaching job, some cultural impact, what? Each of those requires a different level of commitment. Or, more precisely, different commitments.

As far as the earlier comments about creativity under deadlines: A deadline helps to separate the wheat from the chaff asap, when a goalless creative exercise might otherwise drag on, hindering following ideas. Additionally, creative solutions often come from the limits in place from a client. "Deadline" creativity's productiveness compliments abstract creativity's loftiness.

_And bastardization? Well sure, I didn’t invent rounded type!_

Yeah!, that's exactly what I'm talking about Nick. Like in every other field of design there are those who break new ground and then those who follow (or worse). It's the authorship of the rounded type which is at one end of designing type and then there is your Softmachine which is at the other end. You know what I mean?

The guy who created rounded type poured his whole being into breaking new ground in the design of type (and I imagin also that his designs spoke of his time, ie Bayer and the school of Bauhaus). So when you came up with your Softmachine your design effort was far less than his, no offense ok? And from the description you gave of vector stroking, can't that be applied to any class of type?

Nick, I hold many copyright designs and several industrial design patents. I was given my first architectural award when I was twenty-seven and was then labelled avant-garde and a visionary. I know first hand (as did my father before me) the price one pays to give their life to design/art. And from what I've been able to find out about the masters in the design of Type - so did they. They would rather design than eat.  
And since I have just recently been involved in the design of Type I have done a couple of font designs (which are no big deal) and I'm currently working a bold new method of script type, which I think is a big deal - although somewhat unusual.

Dan's question of commitment is not so black and white, because as I mentioned before to tweek someone elses work is one level of design commitment - and to come up with new forms is an entirely different level of commitment to the design of Type.

_does that jive with your "infinitely adjustable"?_

It's true that there is a "benchmark" outlining weight for Softmachine, which corresponds to the closest distance between characters, carried through for internal counters -- and this stroke weight has to be set by eye for a specific type size (not without its benefits, for instance making it easy to give the type outline exactly the same stroke weight as rules). Nonetheless, the typographer has the option to choose absolutely any stroke width, for whatever reason, and there are other thicknesses which might suggest themselves, such as the distance between vertical strokes in the letters h,m,n and u. Ultimately, for whatever reason a typographer is outlining some type, such as to get it to stand out against a disruptive backround, the way of working is to adjust the stroke weight till it looks right, and that's why stroking is the best way to handle outlining, not layered weights.

I might also add that the kind of gradient filter effects (bevel, dropshadow) in the garish "gel" specimen I posted above work on plain, not layered type -- and while this was not my initial anticipation of the type's use, its suitability was obvious early on.

Layout application-generated outlining was behind this type from day one, because I've always considered that to be a much better way to apply special effects to type, rather than layering differnt fonts -- in fact this "best practice", initially developed as a faux feature of WP programs in the 1980s, was then introduced as a formatting utility via Quark Xtensions (Xtensis etc.) and add-on Photoshop filters (eg Alien Skin) in the early '90s, before it was "hard formatted" into the default menus of Quark, Photoshop, Fireworks, InDesign, etc. So that's what I'm playing to, not layers, which is a sort of do-it-yourself technique from the late '80s.

_the authorship of the rounded type_

Rounded letterforms are not a typographic invention, but an imitation of other media.  
This could be said of a lot of typographic features, but it's important to distinguish the metrical-system dimension of type as being uniquely typographic, and that's the design space Softmachine addresses.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100926045031im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Round_6107.png)

This is the first rounded type I am aware of, from an 1830s specimen of Caslon & Livermore, presumably derived from brush lettering. Other non-typographic inspirations of rounded lettering are the "Speedball" nib, quite literally a rounded shape on the end of a pen nib, in the late 19th century. There is also neon signage, and Breuer's tubular-framed armchair, both introduced in the 1920s. And the ball-point pen (Biro, 1940s) and Rotring + template (1950s).

In criticizing my use of rounded letter shapes and terminals as unoriginal, you may be confusing form with function, which sets the bar impossibly high for originality, as everything looks like a bit like something else. The purpose of Softmachine's rounded terminals is to facilitate outlining -- by allowing an even stroke between characters, and by minimizing the opportunity for pointy artefacts that occur when corners are algorithmically enlarged: this is my claim for originality.

Surely this principle -- function not form -- is something you can understand from your experience with design patents?

_your design effort was far less than his, no offense ok?_

None taken. I'm in two minds about the "design effort" of the person who produced that Caslon example. Sure, it was swiped from the signwriters, but the type designer had his own problems in making the concept work typographically, in terms of fit and colour -- things which signwriters, working large and custom, could easily fudge. At any rate, the concept of a rounded type must have been quite outrageous at the time, _highly_ original, shall we say. But how does that discount the lesser, though quite specific, originality of my repurposing of roundedness?

The beauty of using the outline tool is that experimenting with different stroke weights and tracking is so simple. This file took me a couple of minutes (and that includes experiments not shown), whereas with layering it would have been a pain.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100926045031im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Outlines_4031.png)

Here, the top four vary the stroke weight against one tracking value, the bottom three vary the tracking against one stroke value.

The second example is the benchmark stroke thickness (note how the line continues into the counters of "s").

The stroke thickness of the third example is not that great, but there are nonetheless still many good ways to stroke and space the face.

I had considered providing more weights of Softmachine, optimized for different stroke thicknesses, but a single font didn't seem like such a bad idea for starters. "instant" masterpiece. That's one end of the spectrum. What's the other end?

I recently finished two sans serif typefaces in 7 weights each, roman and italic, plus a serifed text face -- basic four styles -- all original from scratch, for a newspaper, in four months. Launching in May (so no jury decision on quality yet). Sixty-hour weeks, but it was winter, and a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. My "Guardian", as it were.

Next step is to extend them for general release in OpenType with CE, Greek, Cyrillic, small caps etc., which will take much longer -- especially as it's not commissioned, paying work.
